[[File:Mastodon mascot vector version.svg|alt=A cartoon Mastodon mascot|thumb|The mascot of the Mastodon social network]]
'''Mastodon''' is [[free and open-source software]] for running [[Self-hosting (web services)|self-hosted]] [[social networking service]]s.{{Efn|Mastodon itself is not a social network, but merely one of the multiple software implementations of the ActivityPub protocol. In common usage, however, it is referred to as a social network.}} It has [[microblogging]] features similar to [[Twitter|X (formerly Twitter)]], which are offered by a large number of independently run [[Node (networking)|nodes]], known as [[Instance (computer science)|instances]] or servers, each with its own [[code of conduct]], [[terms of service]], [[privacy policy]], privacy options, and [[content moderation]] policies.<ref name="Chan 2022">{{cite news |last=Chan |first=Wilfred |title=Mastodon gained 70,000 users after Musk's Twitter takeover. I joined them |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/nov/01/mastodon-twitter-elon-musk-takeover |access-date=3 November 2022 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=2 November 2022}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news |last=Farokhmanesh |first=Megan|date=7 April 2017 |title=A beginner's guide to Mastodon, the hot new open-source Twitter clone |url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/4/7/15183128/mastodon-open-source-twitter-clone-how-to-use|access-date=4 February 2021 |work=[[The Verge]] |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Wong |first=Joon Ian |title=How to use Mastodon, the Twitter alternative that's becoming super popular |url=https://qz.com/951078/the-complete-guide-to-using-mastodon-the-twitter-twtr-alternative/|access-date= 4 February 2021 |work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]] |date=6 April 2017 |language=en}}</ref>

Each user is a member of a specific Mastodon server that can interact seamlessly with users in any other server. This is intended to give users the flexibility to select a server whose policies they prefer, but keep access to a larger [[federated social network]]. Mastodon is powered by the [[ActivityPub]] protocol, making it part of the [[Fediverse]] ensemble of services such as[[Lemmy (software) | Lemmy]], [[Pixelfed]], [[Friendica]], [[PeerTube]], and [[Threads (social network)|Threads]].

Mastodon was created by [[Eugen Rochko]] and announced on [[Hacker News]] in October 2016.<ref>{{cite web |date=2016-10-05 |title=Show HN: A new decentralized microblogging platform |url=https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=12646083 |access-date=2022-10-31}}</ref> It gained significant adoption in 2022 in the wake of [[Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk|Twitter's acquisition by Elon Musk]].<ref name=":3" /><ref name=MSN1/><ref name=CNET1/>

The project is maintained by the German [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit]] Mastodon [[gGmbH]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Knight|first=Will|title=The Man Behind Mastodon Built It for This Moment|language=en-US|magazine=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|url=https://www.wired.com/story/the-man-behind-mastodon-eugen-rochko-built-it-for-this-moment/|access-date=2023-03-05|issn=1059-1028}}</ref> Mastodon development is [[crowdfunded]] and the code does not support advertisements.

==Functionality and features==
Mastodon servers run social networking software that is capable of communicating using [[World Wide Web Consortium|W3C]]'s [[ActivityPub]] standard, which has been implemented since version 1.6.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/releases/tag/v1.6.0|title=Release 1.6.0|website=github.com}}</ref> A Mastodon user can therefore interact with users on any other server in the [[Fediverse]] that supports ActivityPub.

Since version 2.9.0, Mastodon has offered a single-column mode for new users by default.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/06/mastodon-2.9/|title=Mastodon 2.9|website=Official Mastodon Blog|date=14 June 2019 |language=en|access-date=2019-06-16}}</ref> In advanced mode, Mastodon approximates the microblogging user experience of [[TweetDeck]]. Users post short-form status messages, historically known as "toots",<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-11-15 |title=Mastodon Has Officially Retired the 'Toot,' Its Version of the Tweet |url=https://gizmodo.com/mastodon-toot-retired-twitter-tweet-equivalent-1849786221 |access-date=2023-06-02 |website=Gizmodo |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.nottingham.ac.uk/makingsciencepublic/2022/11/11/its-not-a-retoot-is-it-moving-between-platforms-and-languages/|title='It's not a retoot is it?' Moving between platforms and languages|first=Brigitte|last=Nerlich|date=11 November 2022|website=Making Science Public}}</ref> for others to see. On a standard Mastodon instance, these messages can include up to 500 text-based characters, greater than Twitter's 280-character limit. Some instances support even longer messages.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/9/26/16363912/twitter-character-limit-increase-280-test|title=Twitter just doubled the character limit for tweets to 280|website=Theverge.com|access-date=3 December 2018|date=26 September 2017}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|title=How To Get Started on Mastodon and Leave Twitter Behind|url=https://www.pcmag.com/how-to/how-to-get-started-on-mastodon-and-leave-twitter-behind|access-date=2021-02-04|website=PCMAG|language=en}}</ref>

Users join a specific Mastodon server, rather than a single centralized website or application. The servers are connected as nodes in a network, and each server can administer its own rules, account privileges, and whether to share messages to and from other servers. Many servers have a theme based on a specific interest. It is also common for servers to be based around a particular locality, region, ethnicity, or country.<ref name="The Verge: beginner" /><ref>{{Cite web|title=Ditt lokale sosiale nettverk — oslo.town|url=https://oslo.town/about|access-date=2020-10-19|website=Mastodon hosted on oslo.town|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title=Tŵt Cymru {{!}} Toot Wales|url=https://toot.wales/about|access-date=2020-10-19|website=Mastodon hosted on toot.wales|language=en}}</ref>

Mastodon includes a number of specific privacy features. Each message has a variety of privacy options available, and users can choose whether the message is public or private. Public messages display on a global feed, known as a timeline, and private messages are only shared on the timelines of the user's followers. Messages can also be marked as unlisted from timelines or direct between users. Users can also mark their accounts as completely private. In the timeline, messages can display with an optional [[content warning]] feature, which requires readers to click on the hidden main body of the message to reveal it. Mastodon servers have used this feature to hide [[spoiler (media)|spoilers]], [[trigger warning]]s, and [[not safe for work]] (NSFW) content, though some accounts use the feature to hide links and thoughts others might not want to read.<ref name=":1" /><ref name="The Verge: beginner" />

Mastodon aggregates messages in local and federated timelines in real time. The local timeline shows messages from users on a singular server, while the federated timeline shows messages across all participating Mastodon servers. Users can communicate across connected Mastodon servers with usernames similar in format to full email addresses.<ref name=":2" /><ref name="The Verge: beginner"/>

=== Content moderation ===
In early 2017, journalists like [[Sarah Jeong]]<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|date=2017-04-04|title=Mastodon Is Like Twitter Without Nazis, So Why Are We Not Using It?|work=Motherboard|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/783akg/mastodon-is-like-twitter-without-nazis-so-why-are-we-not-using-it|access-date=2018-09-21}}</ref> distinguished Mastodon from Twitter for its approach to combating harassment.<ref name="The Verge: beginner" /> Mastodon uses community-based moderation, in which each server can limit or filter out undesirable types of content, while Twitter uses a single, global policy on [[content moderation]]. For example, the Mastodon instance mastodon.social and several other instances ban content that is illegal in Germany or France, including [[Neo-Nazism|Nazi symbolism]], [[Holocaust denial]], and [[Antisemitism in 21st-century Germany|incitement of violence against Jews]]. Other Mastodon instances, however, can choose to take a more lenient approach to such material. Servers can also choose to limit or filter out messages with disparaging content. The main author of the Mastodon software, [[Eugen Rochko]], believes that small, closely related communities deal with unwanted behaviour more effectively than a large company's small safety team.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://medium.com/we-distribute/one-mammoth-of-a-job-an-interview-with-eugen-rochko-of-mastodon-23b159d6796a|title=One Mammoth of a Job: An Interview with Eugen Rochko of Mastodon|website=medium.com/we-distribute|date=9 July 2018|access-date=5 October 2019}}</ref> Users can also block and report others to administrators, much like on Twitter.<ref name="The Verge: beginner" /><ref name="Chan and Wilfred 2023">{{cite news |last1=Chan |first1=Wilfred |title= Thousands fled to Mastodon after Musk bought Twitter. Are they still 'tooting'? | url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/apr/18/mastodon-users-twitter-elon-musk-social-media |newspaper=The Guardian |date=18 April 2023 |access-date=13 June 2023 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230602102140/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2023/apr/18/mastodon-users-twitter-elon-musk-social-media |archive-date=2 June 2023}}</ref>

Instance administrators can block other instances from interacting with their own, an action called ''defederation''. By posting toots [[Hashtag|hashtagged]] with ''#fediblock'', some instance administrators and users alert others of issues requiring moderation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.techdirt.com/2022/12/12/raspberry-pi-shows-how-not-to-mastodon/|title=Raspberry Pi shows how not to Mastodon|last1= Moody | first1= Glyn |date= 12 Dec 2022|accessdate= 13 June 2023| archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20230324080700/https://www.techdirt.com/2022/12/12/raspberry-pi-shows-how-not-to-mastodon/ | archive-date= 24 March 2023 | website= Techdirt}}</ref>

=== Comparison to Twitter ===
{{Cleanup rewrite|contains only a narrowed view of features of Twitter and the goals of Mastodon|date=October 2023}}
Unlike [[Twitter]], Mastodon by default only searches hashtags and mentioned accounts in the Fediverse, not the full text of posts. Some servers allow users to search the full text of their local posts.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.joinmastodon.org/admin/optional/elasticsearch/|title=Full-text search|website=Mastodon documentation site|accessdate=27 December 2022}}</ref><ref name="osint">{{cite web|url=https://www.secjuice.com/mastodon-osint-a-comprehensive-introduction/|title=Mastodon OSINT: A Comprehensive Introduction|last=Hassan|first=Nihad|date=27 November 2022|accessdate=27 December 2022|website=Secjuice}}</ref> Furthermore, searching for posts will only show results from the Mastodon instance the user is on and from parts of the [[Fediverse]] that that instance has cached via federation, not from all posts on all instances. However, services utilizing the ActivityPub protocol exist which allow for searching all posts on all instances as long as users opt-in.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Tootfinder |url=https://www.tootfinder.ch/ |access-date=2024-04-16 |website=www.tootfinder.ch}}</ref>

For similar reasons, only hashtags can appear in a Mastodon instance's trending topics, not arbitrary popular words. Trending topics vary between instances, since individual instances are aware of different subsets of toots from the whole [[Fediverse]].<ref>{{Cite web |title=admin/trends API methods - Mastodon documentation |url=https://docs.joinmastodon.org/methods/admin/trends/ |access-date=2024-04-16 |website=docs.joinmastodon.org |language=en-us}}</ref>

===Versions===
In September 2018, with the release of version 2.5 with redesigned public profile pages, Mastodon marked its 100th release.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2018/09/mastodon-2.5-released|title=Mastodon 2.5 released: Highlights from the changelog|website=blog.joinmastodon.org|date=5 September 2018 |access-date=3 December 2018}}</ref> Mastodon 2.6 was released in October 2018, introducing the possibilities of verified profiles and live, in-stream link previews for images and videos.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2018/10/mastodon-2.6-released|title=Mastodon 2.6 released: Highlights from the changelog|website=Blog.joinmastodon.org|date=31 October 2018 |access-date=3 December 2018}}</ref> Version 2.7, in January 2019, made it possible to search for multiple hashtags at once, instead of searching for just a single hashtag. Version 2.7 has more robust moderation capabilities for server administrators and moderators, while accessibility, such as contrast for users with sight issues, was improved.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/01/mastodon-2.7|title=Mastodon 2.7 released: Highlights from the changelog|website=Blog.joinmastodon.org|date=20 January 2019 |access-date=20 January 2019}}</ref> The ability for users to create and vote in polls, as well as a new invitation system to manage registrations was integrated in April 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/04/mastodon-2.8|title=Mastodon 2.8 Highlights from the changelog|website=blog.joinmastodon.org|date=10 April 2019 |access-date=11 April 2019}}</ref> Mastodon 2.8.1, released in May 2019, made images with content warnings blurred instead of completely hidden.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/05/improving-support-for-adult-content-on-mastodon|title=Improving support for adult content on Mastodon|website=blog.joinmastodon.org|date=5 May 2019 |access-date=6 May 2019}}</ref> In version 2.9 in June 2019, an optional single-column view was added.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/06/mastodon-2.9|title=Introducing the single-column layout|website=blog.joinmastodon.org|date=14 June 2019 |access-date=15 July 2019}}</ref> This view became the default displayed to new users, with a user "preferences" option to switch to a multiple-column-based view.{{Citation needed|date=September 2022}}

In August 2020, Mastodon 3.2 was released. It included a redesigned audio player with custom thumbnails and the ability to add personal notes to one's profile.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Mastodon 3.2|url=http://blog.joinmastodon.org/2020/08/mastodon-3.2/|access-date=2020-08-21|website=Official Mastodon Blog|date=2 August 2020 |language=en}}</ref>

In July 2021, an official client for [[iOS]] devices was released. According to the project's leadership,{{who|date=December 2022}} the release was part of an effort to attract new users.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/7/30/22602275/mastodon-decentralized-social-network-official-ios-app-launches |title=Mastodon now has an official iPhone app |website=The Verge |date=30 July 2021 |access-date=31 July 2021}}</ref>

Mastodon 4.0 was released in November 2022, including language support for translating posts, editing posts and following hashtags.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Release v4.0.0 · mastodon/mastodon |url=https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/releases/tag/v4.0.0 |access-date=2022-11-20 |website=GitHub |language=en}}</ref>

==Software==
{{Expand section|with=more details on technical information|date=November 2018}}
[[File:2024-02-03 FOSDEM 028.jpg|thumb|Two Mastodon developers at the Mastodon booth at [[FOSDEM]] 2024]]
Mastodon is written as [[free and open-source software]] (FOSS) for [[Federated social network|federated]] microblogging, which anybody can contribute code to, and which anyone can run on their own server infrastructure, if they wish, or join servers run by other people<ref>{{cite web|url=https://fediverse.network/mastodon|title=Mastodon Instances — The Fediverse Network|access-date=3 December 2018|archive-date=12 November 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201112031908/https://fediverse.network/mastodon|url-status=dead}}</ref> within the [[fediverse]] network.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://hackernoon.com/welcome-to-mastodon-111d9227e56a|title=Welcome to Mastodon|first=Eugen|last=Rochko|date=1 April 2017|website=Hacker Noon|access-date=3 December 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180912080249/https://hackernoon.com/welcome-to-mastodon-111d9227e56a|archive-date=12 September 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref> Its [[Front and back ends|server-side software]] is powered by [[Ruby on Rails]] and [[Node.js]], and its front end is written in [[React.js]] and [[Redux (JavaScript library)|Redux]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://docs.joinmastodon.org/administration/installation/|title=Installation|access-date=26 December 2018|website=joinmastodon.org|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181227084921/https://docs.joinmastodon.org/administration/installation/|archive-date=27 December 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref> The [[database]] software is [[PostgreSQL]].<ref>{{Citation|title=tootsuite/mastodon|date=2021-02-04|url=https://github.com/tootsuite/mastodon|publisher=Mastodon|access-date=2021-02-04}}</ref> The service is interoperable with the [[decentralized application|decentralized]] social networks and platforms which use the [[ActivityPub]] protocol between each other.<ref name="activitypub">{{cite web|url=https://github.com/tootsuite/mastodon/releases/tag/v1.6.0 |title=Release v1.6.0 |website=GitHub|access-date=2017-09-20}}</ref> Since version 3.0, Mastodon dropped previous support for [[OStatus]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Your self-hosted, globally interconnected microblogging community: tootsuite/mastodon|date=2019-10-04|url=https://github.com/tootsuite/mastodon/releases/tag/v3.0.0|publisher=TootSuite|access-date=2019-10-04}}</ref>

Client apps for interacting with the Mastodon API are available for desktop computer operating systems, including [[Windows (operating system)|Windows]], [[macOS]] and the [[Linux]] family of operating systems, and on [[mobile phone]] systems, including [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] and [[List of open-source mobile phones|open-source mobile phones]].<ref name=":2" /><ref name="apps">{{cite web|url=https://joinmastodon.org/apps |title=List of apps |website=joinmastodon.org|access-date=2022-02-12|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220127104448/https://joinmastodon.org/apps|archive-date=27 January 2022}}</ref>

==Adoption==
[[File:What is Mastodon.webm|thumb|Introductory video explaining Mastodon]]
While Mastodon was first released in October 2016, the service began to expand in late March and early April 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://au.pcmag.com/social-networking/47343/feature/what-is-mastodon-and-will-it-kill-twitter|title=What Is Mastodon and Will It Kill Twitter?|date=2017-04-06|website=PCMag Australia|first=Chandra|last=Steele}}</ref>  Servers were mostly operated by academic institutions, journalists, hobbyists, and activists.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Klemmens |first=Ben |date=2023-01-02 |title=Mastodon—and the pros and cons of moving beyond Big Tech gatekeepers |url=https://arstechnica.com/gadgets/2023/01/mastodon-highlights-pros-and-cons-of-moving-beyond-big-tech-gatekeepers/ |access-date=2023-01-18 |website=Ars Technica |language=en-us}}</ref> ''[[The Verge]]'' wrote that the community at this time was small and that it had yet to attract the personalities that keep users at Twitter.<ref name="The Verge: beginner"/> The global use had risen from 766,500 users as of 1 August 2017, to 1 million users on 1 December 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://mnm.eliotberriot.com/dashboard/db/network-drilldown?refresh=30m&orgId=1&orgId=1&from=now-7d&to=now |title= dynamic status of mastodon|website=Eliotberriott.com|access-date= 16 April 2017}}{{dead link|date=October 2019}}</ref><ref name="dec2017onemil">{{cite news|title=Mastodon Users (bot), December 1, 2017, 4:00 PM|url=https://lou.lt/@mastodonusercount/99099871022836220|newspaper=Loultstodon|date=December 2017 |access-date=1 December 2017}}</ref> In{{Nbsp}}November 2017 artists, writers, and entrepreneurs such as [[Chuck Wendig]], [[John Scalzi]], [[Melanie Gillman]] and later John O'Nolan joined in.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite news |last=Bonnington |first=Christina |url=http://www.dailydot.com/debug/mastodon-open-source-social-media/ |title=Mastodon is an open source, decentralized version of Twitter |work=[[The Daily Dot]] |date=2016-11-22 |access-date=2017-01-11 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Tidey |first=Jimmy |url=https://www.opendemocracy.net/en/what-would-twitter-be-with-wikipedia-politics/ |title=What would Twitter be if it adopted Wikipedia's politics? |work=[[openDemocracy]] |date=2017-01-06 |access-date=2017-01-11 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chronicle.com/blogs/profhacker/are-you-on-mastodon-yet-social-network-of-our-own/63261|title=Are You on Mastodon Yet? Social Network of Our Own – ProfHacker - Blogs - The Chronicle of Higher Education|website=Chronicle.com|access-date=2018-09-21|date=28 November 2016}}</ref>

Another spike in popularity came in March through April 2018, due to the concerns about user privacy raised by the ''#deletefacebook'' effort.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/business/facebook-deletefacebook-mastodon-zuckerberg-cambridge-analytica-20180323.html|title=Facebook's poor care of customer data is driving users to social networks such as Mastodon|first=Brian|last=Fung|agency=Washington Post|website=www.philly.com|date=23 March 2018 }}</ref>

Membership of Mastodon and other alternative social media sites increased in early December 2018<ref>{{cite web |title=User Count Bot |url=https://mastodon.social/@usercount |website=Mastodon.social |access-date=2018-12-03}}</ref>{{Better source needed|date=December 2022|reason=Should have a secondary source.}} after [[Tumblr]] announced its intention to ban all adult content from the site.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Gibson |first1=Kate |title=Tumblr banning adult content starting Dec. 17, citing porn concerns |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/tumblr-banning-adult-content-starting-dec-17-citing-porn-concerns/ |access-date=3 December 2018 |work=CBS News |date=3 December 2018}}</ref>

In November 2019, nearly 20,000 Twitter users in India temporarily shifted to Mastodon over complaints by users against Twitter's moderation policies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://qz.com/india/1746734/angry-twitter-india-users-are-migrating-to-mastodon-in-thousands/|title=This chart from Mastodon's creator shows just how angry some Indian Twitter users are|last=Kapur|first=Manavi|website=Quartz India|date=12 November 2019 |language=en|access-date=2019-11-14}}</ref>

To circumvent the increasing online censorship of social networks in mainland China, an increasing number of Chinese-language users have chosen to migrate to Mastodon in 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/as-china-tightens-controls-on-social-media-some-users-seek-refuge-under-the-radar-11659551841|title=As China Tightens Controls on Social Media, Some Users Seek Refuge Under the Radar|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=2022-08-04|first=Lu|last=Shen}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url= https://www.scmp.com/tech/tech-trends/article/3192843/chinese-social-media-users-are-flocking-decentralised-mastodon|title= Chinese social media users are flocking to the decentralised Mastodon platform to find community amid crackdown at home|work=SCMP|date=2022-09-18}}</ref>

===2022 Twitter-related spikes in adoption===
{{see also|December 15, 2022 Twitter suspensions}}
A spike in Mastodon's user participation occurred in April 2022, following the 25{{nbsp}}April announcement of [[Acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk|Elon Musk purchasing Twitter]]. By 27{{nbsp}}April, {{val|30000|fmt=commas}} new users had joined Mastodon.<ref name="Engadget_after_Musks_Twitter_takeover" /><ref name="OKOpress_Musk_bought_Twitter" /> On 28{{nbsp}}April 2022, the [[European Data Protection Supervisor]] (EDPS) launched the official ActivityPub microblogging platform ([https://social.network.europa.eu EU{{nbsp}}Voice]) of the EU institutions, bodies and agencies (EUIs), based on Mastodon.<ref>''[https://edps.europa.eu/press-publications/press-news/press-releases/2022/edps-launches-pilot-phase-two-social-media_en EDPS launches pilot phase of two social media platforms]'' (press release).</ref>

Musk's acquisition became final on 27{{nbsp}}October 2022. Mastodon had an increase of {{val|70,000|fmt=commas}} new users from a resultant "[[diaspora]]" on 28 October alone.<ref name="chan-2022">{{cite news|last1=Chan|first1=Wilfred|title=Mastodon gained 70,000 users after Musk's Twitter takeover. I joined them|date=2 November 2022|work=The Guardian|location=London, United Kingdom|issn=0261-3077|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2022/nov/01/mastodon-twitter-elon-musk-takeover|access-date = 2022-11-02}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Twitter: 70,000 users join rival Mastodon after Musk takeover |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/technology/twitter-70000-users-join-rival-mastodon-after-musk-takeover/ar-AA13CEYX |access-date=2022-11-12 |website=MSN |language=en-US}}</ref> Daily downloads increased substantially, rising from 3,400 daily downloads on 27 October to 113,400 on 6 November 2022.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Fischer |first=Sara |date=2022-11-08 |title=Musk's Twitter chaos opens door for challengers |url=https://www.axios.com/2022/11/08/twitter-challengers-rise-musk-chaos |access-date=2022-11-09 |website=Axios |language=en}}</ref> According to Rochko, by 3 November, use of the federated network had grown to 665,000 active users, with a few growing pains. In particular, Mastodon's largest instance, mastodon.social, needed capacity upgrades to handle the new load.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2022/11/03/decentralized-social-network-mastodon-grows-to-655k-users-in-wake-of-elon-musks-twitter-takeover/|title=Decentralized social network Mastodon grows to 655K users in wake of Elon Musk's Twitter takeover|first=Sarah|last=Perez|date=3 November 2022}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Metz |first=Rachel |date=2022-11-05 |title=With Twitter in chaos, Mastodon is on fire {{!}} CNN Business |url=https://www.cnn.com/2022/11/05/tech/mastodon/index.html |access-date=2022-11-15 |website=CNN |language=en}}</ref> Accounts on a server called journa.host founded by [[Adam Davidson (journalist)|Adam Davidson]] are restricted to professional journalists.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chaos on Twitter Leads a Group of Journalists to Start an Alternative |work=The New York Times |date=21 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230627042336/https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/21/style/mastodon-twitter-adam-davidson.html |archive-date=27 June 2023 |url-status=live |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2022/11/21/style/mastodon-twitter-adam-davidson.html |last1=Bernstein |first1=Joseph }}</ref>

Mastodon's increased adoption continued in the days following the Twitter takeover. On 11 November, the number of new users of the platform compared to the previous week was reported to be 700,000,<ref name=MSN1>{{Cite web |title=How to Join Mastodon? Be Patient and Kind |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/technology/how-to-join-mastodon-be-patient-and-kind/ar-AA13Xmg1 |access-date=2022-11-12 |website=MSN |language=en-US}}</ref> moving Mastodon over the 7 million user mark.<ref name=CNET1>{{cite web | url=https://www.cnet.com/tech/services-and-software/twitter-in-turmoil-heres-how-to-join-the-mastodon-social-network/ | title=Confused by Twitter 'Replacement' Mastodon? Here's How to Get Started | website=CNET}}</ref> During that period, several prominent figures joined Mastodon, including prominent actors, comedians, journalists, political activists, and politicians.<ref>{{Cite web |title=15+ Famous Celebrities On Mastodon 2022! |date= 24 November 2022 |url= https://deasilex.com/celebrities-on-mastodon/ |access-date=2022-12-02 |language=en-US}}</ref> In December 2022, the number of monthly active users of Mastodon reached two million.<ref>{{cite web |title=Servers |url=https://joinmastodon.org/servers |publisher=Mastodon |access-date=16 December 2022}}</ref>

On 15 December, the official Mastodon Twitter account was banned from Twitter, [[December 15, 2022 Twitter suspensions|as well as other accounts with links to some Mastodon instances]].<ref>{{Cite web |last=Taylor |first=Hatmaker |date=16 December 2022 |title=Twitter suspends Mastodon's account and bans links to Mastodon servers |url=https://techcrunch.com/2022/12/15/elon-musk-suspends-mastodon-twitter-account-over-elonjet-tracking/?guccounter=1 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221216100905/https://techcrunch.com/web/20221216100905/https://techcrunch.com/2022/12/15/elon-musk-suspends-mastodon-twitter-account-over-elonjet-tracking/ |archive-date=16 December 2022 |website=TechCrunch}}</ref> On the following day, Twitter began to flag all Mastodon links as malware, preventing Twitter users from sharing them.<ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-63999452 Twitter blocks users from sharing Mastodon links] [[BBC News]]</ref><ref>[https://www.cnn.com/2022/12/16/tech/mastodon-twitter-links/index.html Elon Musk's Twitter blocked links to rival Mastodon. That could raise alarms among regulators] [[CNN]]</ref> A [[Mediaite]] opinion piece on the bannings included an erroneous report of an account for "John Mastodon" (a misspelling of ''@joinmastodon''), "founder of a competing social media company named after himself", being banned.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Schorr |first=Isaac |date=2022-12-16 |title=Hypocrisy and Fear All the Way Down at Twitter |work=Mediaite |url=https://www.mediaite.com/opinion/hypocrisy-and-fear-all-the-way-down-at-twitter/ |access-date=2022-12-18 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221216232836/https://www.mediaite.com/opinion/hypocrisy-and-fear-all-the-way-down-at-twitter/ |archive-date=2022-12-16}}</ref> Subsequently, Mastodon users wrote fictional backstories and memes about "John Mastodon" and circulated the [[hashtag]] ''#JohnMastodon''.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Frauenfelder |first=Mark |date=2022-12-18 |title=Mastodon users embrace columnist's funny error about a fictitious "John Mastodon" |url=https://boingboing.net/2022/12/18/mastodon-users-embrace-columnists-funny-error-about-a-fictitious-john-mastodon.html |access-date=2022-12-18 |website=Boing Boing |language=en-US}}</ref>

Following the Mastodon suspension and ban on Mastodon links on Twitter,<ref>[https://www.theverge.com/2022/12/15/23512113/twitter-blocking-mastodon-links-elon-musk-elonjet Twitter is blocking links to Mastodon], [[The Verge]]</ref> Twitter introduced a new policy on 18 December to prohibit sharing links on Twitter to a variety of social media websites, with Mastodon being one of those blocked. The policy stated that it prohibited links in both tweets and account details and that accounts that violated the policy would be suspended.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2022/12/18/business/twitter-ban-social-media-competitors-mastodon.html Twitter to Ban Accounts That Promote Rival Social Media], ''[[The New York Times]]''</ref><ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/twitter-policy-idCAKBN2T20CH Elon Musk launches poll asking if he should quit as Twitter CEO], [[Reuters]]</ref><ref>[https://www.theverge.com/2022/12/18/23515221/twitter-bans-links-instagram-mastodon-competitors Twitter abruptly bans all links to Instagram, Mastodon, and other competitors] The Verge</ref> By 19 December, the policy and official mentions about it had been removed from Twitter web pages.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2022/12/18/twitter-bans-links-facebook-instagram-mastodon-accounts/10921759002 Twitter deletes new policy banning 'free promotion' of rival social media platforms], ''[[USA Today]]''</ref><ref>[https://gizmodo.com/elon-musk-twitter-external-links-mastodon-1849909896 Twitter Suddenly Reverses Course on 'Policy' That Banned Links to Competing Social Media Sites], [[Gizmodo]]</ref> Musk stated the following day that banning users for posting Mastodon links had been a mistake.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/tech/elon-musk-delete-mastodon-twitter-b2249096.html Elon Musk says taking down accounts for posting links of rival Mastodon was 'a mistake'], ''[[The Independent]]''</ref>

Rochko claimed that at least five [[venture capital]] firms looking to invest in Mastodon had been turned away by December 2022, and that Mastodon's nonprofit status would not be jeopardized.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Times |first=Financial |date=2022-12-28 |title=Twitter rival Mastodon rejects funding to preserve nonprofit status |url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2022/12/twitter-rival-mastodon-rejects-funding-to-preserve-nonprofit-status/ |website=Ars Technica |language=en-us}}</ref>

By the start of January 2023, Mastodon had 1.8 million active users, down 30% from its peak of over 2.5 million active users in early December 2022.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Nicholas |first1=Josh |title=Elon Musk drove more than a million people to Mastodon – but many aren't sticking around |url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2023/jan/08/elon-musk-drove-more-than-a-million-people-to-mastodon-but-many-arent-sticking-around |website=The Guardian |date=7 January 2023 |access-date=9 January 2023}}</ref> On 19 March 2023, Mastodon passed the ten million mark for registered user accounts.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.itworldcanada.com/article/mastodon-passes-the-10-million-account-milestone/533720 | title=Mastodon passes the 10 million account milestone | IT World Canada News | date=20 March 2023 }}</ref> In a July 2023 post, Rochko said that monthly active users was trending up and had crossed the 2-million mark.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://mastodon.social/@Gargron/110758117937490286 |date=July 22, 2023 |website=mastodon.social |title=Mastodon Social}}</ref> Following Elon Musk's acquisition of Twitter, there has been a surge in the number of users migrating to other platforms.<ref>{{cite arXiv |last1=Jeong |first1=Ujun |title=Exploring Platform Migration Patterns between Twitter and Mastodon: A User Behavior Study |date=2023-11-19  |eprint=2305.09196 |last2=Sheth |first2=Paras |last3=Tahir |first3=Anique |last4=Alatawi |first4=Faisal |last5=Bernard |first5=H. Russell |last6=Liu |first6=Huan|class=cs.SI }}</ref> Among these, Mastodon is widely regarded as one of the most promising alternatives in the competitive social media landscape,<ref>{{cite arXiv |last1=Jeong |first1=Ujun |title=User Migration across Multiple Social Media Platforms |date=2023-09-22 |eprint=2309.12613 |last2=Nirmal |first2=Ayushi |last3=Jha |first3=Kritshekhar |last4=Tang |first4=Xu |last5=Bernard |first5=H. Russell |last6=Liu |first6=Huan|class=cs.SI }}</ref> standing out among others like [[Threads (social network)|Threads]] and [[Bluesky (social network)|Bluesky]].

Finance|date=2023-12-20|access-date=2023-09-24}}</ref> Pawoo is banned by most instances on Mastodon due to allowing {{transl|ja|[[lolicon]]}} art.<ref>{{cite news | first1=April | last1=Glaser | first2=Will | last2=Oremus | url=https://slate.com/technology/2018/08/mastodon-what-you-need-to-know-about-the-new-social-network-competing-with-twitter.html | title=The New Social Network Dodging Government Surveillance—and Nazis | work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] | date=2018-08-30 | accessdate=2022-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | first=Ethan | last=Zuckerman | authorlink=Ethan Zuckerman | url=https://ethanzuckerman.com/2017/08/18/mastodon-is-big-in-japan-the-reason-why-is-uncomfortable | title=Mastodon is big in Japan. [[Gab (social network)|Gab]], a controversial social network with a [[Far-right politics|far-right]] user base, changed its software platform to a fork of Mastodon and became the largest Mastodon node in July 2019.<ref>{{cite web|first1=Ben|last1=Makuch|first2=Jason|last2=Koebler|first3=Derek|last3=Mead|access-date=2019-07-17|title=Mastodon Was Designed to Be a Nazi-Free Twitter—Now It's the Exact Opposite|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/mb8y3x/the-nazi-free-alternative-to-twitter-is-now-home-to-the-biggest-far-right-social-network|date=11 July 2019|website=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]}}</ref> Gab's adoption of Mastodon allowed Gab to be accessed from third-party Mastodon applications, although four of them blocked Gab shortly after the change.<ref>{{cite web|first1=Adi|last1=Robertson|access-date=2019-07-17|title=How the biggest decentralized social network is dealing with its Nazi problem|url=https://www.theverge.com/2019/7/12/20691957/mastodon-decentralized-social-network-gab-migration-fediverse-app-blocking|date=12 July 2019|website=[[The Verge]]}}</ref> In response, Mastodon's main contributors stated in their blog that they were "completely opposed to Gab’s project and philosophy", and criticized Gab for attempting "to monetize and platform [[racist]] content while hiding behind the banner of free speech" and for "[[paywall]]ing basic features that are freely available on Mastodon".<ref>{{cite web|access-date=2019-07-17|title=Statement on Gab's fork of Mastodon|url=http://blog.joinmastodon.org/2019/07/statement-on-gabs-fork-of-mastodon/|website=Official Mastodon Blog|author=Eleanor|date=4 July 2019}}</ref>

In October 2019, the Fourth Estate Public Benefit Corporation released a fork of Mastodon named Civiq.Social.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.fourthestate.org/news/announcing-the-launch-of-civiq/|title=Announcing the launch of Project Civiq|date=24 October 2019|website=Fourth Estate|access-date=24 October 2019}}</ref>

''Tooter'' is an Indian [[social networking]] product launched in September 2020. Tooter is forked (derived) from the main branch of Mastodon software.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.arre.co.in/technology/how-swadeshi-is-tooter-if-it-clones-far-right-platforms-like-gab/amp/?__twitter_impression=true | title=How "Swadeshi" is Tooter If It Clones Far-Right Platforms Like Gab? | publisher=arre.co.in | date=27 November 2020 | access-date=19 December 2020 }}</ref>

In October 2021, former US President [[Donald Trump]] founded [[Truth Social]], which is based on Mastodon.<ref name="Chan 2022" /> Initially, Truth Social did not make its [[source code]] available, violating Mastodon's [[AGPLv3]] license. Eugen Rochko sent a formal letter to Truth Social's chief legal officer on 26 October 2021.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Rochko |first1=Eugen |title=Trump's new social media platform found using Mastodon code |url=https://blog.joinmastodon.org/2021/10/trumps-new-social-media-platform-found-using-mastodon-code/ |website=Mastodon Blog |date=October 29, 2021}}</ref> On 12 November 2021, Truth Social published its source code.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kan |first1=Michael |title=Trump's Social Media Site Quietly Admits It's Based on Mastodon |url=https://uk.pcmag.com/social-media/137421/trumps-social-media-site-quietly-admits-its-based-on-mastodon |website=[[PCMag]] |date=December 1, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://help.truthsocial.com/legal/open-source/|title=What's Open Source?|work=Truth Social Help Center|accessdate=2024-04-04}}</ref>

== Security ==
{{One source section|date=May 2023}}
While Mastodon's decentralized structure is one of its most distinctive features, it also poses additional security challenges.

Since many Mastodon instances are run by volunteers, some security experts are concerned about data security and responsiveness to new threats (like high-severity vulnerabilities) considering the difficulty of configuring and maintaining servers as well as uneven skill level among administrators. Errors in instance configuration and security bugs in server implementation has already led to user data being scraped or changed by attackers. It is worth noting that Mastodon collects considerably less personal data, compared to other social media platforms which makes it a lower-value target and potential losses less significant.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web |last=Goodin |first=Dan |date=2022-11-29 |title=How secure a Twitter replacement is Mastodon? Let us count the ways |url=https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2022/11/how-secure-a-twitter-replacement-is-mastodon-let-us-count-the-ways/ |access-date=2023-01-28 |website=[[Ars Technica]] |language=en-us}}</ref>

Eugen Rochko argues{{Citation needed|reason=Where?|date=August 2023}} that these issues do not set it apart from other software products that can be hosted by non-professionals.

In 2023, the [[Mozilla Foundation]] contracted with [[Cure53]] to perform [[penetration testing]] on the Mastodon software, in preparation for establishing an instance for the Mozilla community. The testing discovered several vulnerabilities, including one called "TootRoot" that would have enabled [[arbitrary code execution]] and another that would have enabled [[cross-site scripting]] attacks through [[oEmbed]] cards. These vulnerabilities were patched in July 2023.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mastodon fixes critical "TootRoot" vulnerability allowing node hijacking|first=Dan|last=Goodin|work=[[Ars Technica]]|date=July 6, 2023|accessdate=July 6, 2023|url=https://arstechnica.com/security/2023/07/mastodon-fixes-critical-tootroot-vulnerability-allowing-node-hijacking/}}</ref>

Another issue can be content moderation. While Mastodon instances can limit or filter out undesirable types of content, a large-scale harassment and misinformation campaign may require active moderation.<ref name=":4" />

Mastodon currently delays fix for link previews.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Connatser |first=Matthew |title=Mastodon delays firm fix to solve link preview DDoS |url=https://www.theregister.com/2024/05/06/mastodon_delays_fix_ddos/ |access-date=2024-05-17 |website=www.theregister.com |language=en}}</ref>

==Funding==
Mastodon is [[crowdfunded]] and does not contain ads; as of November 2022, it was supported by 3,500 people. Since 2021 it has been registered in Germany as a [[nonprofit organization]] ({{lang-de|gemeinnützige [[GmbH]]}}).<ref>{{Cite news| last=Glanz |first=Berit |title=Twitter-Alternative: Wer steckt eigentlich hinter Mastodon? |language=de |work=FAZ.NET |url=https://www.faz.net/aktuell/feuilleton/medien/twitter-alternative-mastodon-wer-steckt-hinter-der-plattform-18450637.html |access-date=2022-11-14 |issn=0174-4909}}</ref>
